values.content:
You are an expert SEO content optimizer specialized in creating meta tags for both web pages and blog articles. Your task is to analyze the provided content and generate optimized meta tags based on the content type.

META TAG REQUIREMENTS:

1. Meta Title (max 60 characters):
   - Include primary keyword near the beginning
   - State the main value proposition
   - Include brand name when relevant
   - Use action-oriented language for commercial pages
   - Format: Primary Keyword | Main Benefit | Brand (if applicable)

2. Meta Description (max 160 characters):
   - Lead with unique selling proposition
   - Include primary and secondary keywords naturally
   - Add clear call-to-action
   - Highlight key benefits or features
   - Address user pain points
   - Tease the main insights or findings
   - Mention key topics covered
   - Use engaging question or statement
   - Include expertise indicators
   - Promise value or solution

OUTPUT FORMAT:
Please provide meta tags in the required format

VALIDATION CHECKLIST:
- Title length ≤ 60 characters
- Description length ≤ 160 characters
- Primary keyword included in both
- Matches identified search intent
- Appropriate for content type
- Clear value proposition
- Compelling call-to-action
- Natural keyword placement
- Proper grammar and spelling
- Mobile display optimized
- Don't use placeholder

Remember: The goal is to create meta tags that serve both search engines and users effectively while maintaining specificity for the content type and maximizing organic click-through rates.

parameters.content:
## Publish & Distribute Sub-Workflow

**Purpose:** Shared publishing workflow for all article types

**Features:**
1. Smart internal linking (Settlement/Complaint only)
2. Title generation (Claude Haiku)
3. WordPress draft creation
4. Featured image generation (DALL-E)
5. SEO metadata (GPT-4o)
6. Database update for future linking
7. Success response

**Token Optimization:**
- Internal linking uses article database (not full content)
- Reduces token consumption by ~80%

**Workflow Logic:**
- IF article type = settlement OR complaint
  → Apply internal linking
- ELSE
  → Skip linking, go straight to title generation

**Setup Required:**
- WordPress credentials
- Anthropic API key
- OpenAI API key
- Data Table ID

This workflow is called by all article sub-workflows.

json.articleHtml:
Emerald City Fence Companies Agree to $350,000 Class Action Settlement Over Meal and Rest Break Violations

Settlement at a Glance

  • Defendants: Emerald City Statewide, LLC, Emerald City Fence Rentals, LLC, and Statewide Rent-A-Fence, Inc.
  • Settlement Amount: $350,000
  • Class Fund for Workers: $248,500
  • Claim Filing Deadline: No claim form required - automatic payment
  • Proof Required: None - if you qualify, you will be paid automatically
  • Estimated Payout: Varies by worker based on hours worked and pay structure
  • Case Number: King County Superior Court Civil Case No. 18-2-25138-9 SEA

Table of Contents

  • What Is This Settlement About?
  • Who Qualifies?
  • How Much Can You Get?
  • How to Get Your Payment
  • Important Deadlines
  • Excluding Yourself from the Settlement
  • How to Object
  • Frequently Asked Questions
  • Settlement Document

What Is This Settlement About?

Former employee Daniel Barrett filed a class action lawsuit against Emerald City Statewide, LLC, Emerald City Fence Rentals, LLC, and Statewide Rent-A-Fence, Inc. (collectively referred to as "Emerald City Fence" or "the defendants") alleging violations of Washington State wage and hour laws. Specifically, Barrett claimed that the companies failed to provide employees with legally compliant meal periods and rest breaks as required under Washington law during the period from October 5, 2015, through December 31, 2018.

The lawsuit alleged that workers were denied proper meal and rest breaks, or that the breaks provided did not meet the requirements established by Washington State regulations. These alleged violations could have resulted in unpaid wages, overtime, penalties, and interest for affected workers. Barrett brought the case on behalf of himself and other similarly situated employees who worked for the fence rental companies during the relevant time period.

The defendants have strongly denied all allegations of wrongdoing and maintain that they complied with all applicable labor laws. However, to avoid the cost and uncertainty of continued litigation, both parties agreed to settle the case for $350,000. The settlement does not constitute an admission of liability or wrongdoing by the defendants. The settlement class representative and his attorneys believe this settlement is fair, adequate, and reasonable, and serves the best interests of the affected workers.

Who Qualifies?

You May Qualify If...

  • You were employed by Emerald City Statewide, LLC, Emerald City Fence Rentals, LLC, or Statewide Rent-A-Fence, Inc. at any time between October 5, 2015, and December 31, 2018
  • You were paid on an hourly basis during your employment
  • You were paid on a piece rate basis during your employment
  • You worked in a position that was not solely office-based
  • You performed manual labor or fiel

infographic.description: Create an interactive visual decision tree infographic that guides workers through qualification criteria for the Emerald City Fence settlement. The design should feature a top-to-bottom flow starting with a welcoming header stating 'Check Your Eligibility' with the $350,000 settlement amount prominently displayed. Below, implement 4-5 sequential decision nodes representing key criteria: (1) Employment period verification (October 5, 2015 - December 31, 2018) with a calendar icon, (2) Company name matching (Emerald City Statewide, LLC; Emerald City Fence Rentals, LLC; or Statewide Rent-A-Fence, Inc.) with company logos or checkmarks, (3) Pay type verification (hourly or piece rate) with dollar sign icons, and (4) Job type confirmation (non-office-based manual labor or field work) with worker silhouettes. Each criterion should branch into 'Yes' and 'No' paths using arrows or directional elements. The 'Yes' path continues to the next criterion, while 'No' paths lead to a compassionate message explaining they may not qualify. The final 'Yes' result should display an encouraging message with next steps and the claim filing information. Use a color palette of green for positive outcomes, neutral grays for questions, and include icons that represent each criterion. Incorporate subtle background elements related to fence work without overwhelming the content.
